           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. support, maintenance, wages &amp;c. (= <em>bh&#x1e5b;ti</em>). <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>bh&#x1e5b;&#x0301;gu</em> m. pl. (&#x221a;<em>bhr&#x0101;j</em>) N. of a mythical race of beings (closely connected with fire, which they find [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 46, 2] and bring to men [i, 58, 6 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 195, 2] or enclose in wood [vi, 15, 2] or put in the navel of the world [i, 143, 4] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or which is brought to them and first kindled by M&#x0101;tari-&#x015b;van [i, 60, 1 ; iii, 5, 10] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they are also said to fabricate chariots [iv, 16, 20] and are mentioned together with the A&#x1e45;girasas, Atharvans, &#x1e5a;ibhus, Maruts, Druhyus &amp;c. [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> Naigh. v, 5] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcat">Hcat.</a> 12 Bh&#x1e5b;igus are enumerated among gods </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gk">Gk.</a> ?) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kau&#x015b;">Kau&#x015b;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of one of the chief [765, 1] Br&#x0101;hmanical families (to which the Aita&#x015b;&#x0101;yanas are said to belong) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> (esp. vii, 18, 6 ; viii, 3, 9 &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to be divided or penetrated or betrayed or refuted ( <em>a-</em>, <em>dur-</em>, <em>nir-bh&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; bhaimi </dt>
           <dd><em>bhaimi</em>, m. (fr. <em>bh&#x012b;ma</em>) patr. of Gha&#x1e6d;&#x00f4;tkaca <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a></dd>

           <dt>bhairava </dt>
           <dd><em>bhairava</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em> and <em>&#x012b;</em>)n. (fr. <em>bh&#x012b;ru</em>) frightful, terrible, horrible, formidable (<em>am</em> ind.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; relating to Bhairava <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of a form of &#x015a;iva (cf <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 85) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Prab">Prab.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> (in the latter 8 Bhairava's are enumerated, viz. <em>mah&#x0101;-</em>, <em>sa&#x1e43;h&#x0101;ra-</em>, <em>asit&#x00e2;&#x1e45;ga-</em>, <em>ruru-</em> <em>k&#x0101;la-</em>, <em>krodha-</em>, <em>t&#x0101;mrac&#x016b;&#x1e0d;a-</em>, or <em>kap&#x0101;la-</em>, <em>candrac&#x016b;&#x1e0d;a-</em> or <em>rudra-bh&#x25cb;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes other names are given, e.g. <em>vidy&#x0101;-r&#x0101;ja</em>, <em>k&#x0101;ma-r&#x25cb;</em>, <em>n&#x0101;ga-r&#x25cb;</em>, <em>svacchanda-r&#x25cb;</em>, <em>lambita-r&#x25cb;</em>, <em>deva-r&#x25cb;</em>, <em>ugra-r&#x25cb;</em>, <em>vighna-r&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a man representing Bhairava's <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a jackal <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a mountain <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in music) ) N. of a R&#x0101;ga </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a chief of &#x015a;iva's host, K&#x0101;IP </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of &#x015a;iva by T&#x0101;r&#x0101;-vat&#x012b; (wife of Candra-&#x015b;ekhara, king of Karavira-pura) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a N&#x0101;ga <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a Yaksha <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a hunter <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of 2 kings and various teachers and authors (also with <em>trip&#x0101;&#x1e6d;hin</em>, <em>daivaj&#x00f1;a</em>, <em>tilaka</em>, <em>d&#x012b;k&#x1e63;ita</em>, <em>&#x0101;c&#x0101;rya</em>, <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;a</em> and <em>mi&#x015b;ra</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a river <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. N. of a partic. sect <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. N. of Nir&#x1e5b;iti, VYogay </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. of a class of Apsaras <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. below </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. terror or the property of exciting terror <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>bhairava-tantra</em> below</dd>

           <dd><em>bhogi</em> in comp. for 1. <em>bhogin</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; bhogik&#x0101;nta </dt>

           <dt>&#x226b; bhogin 1</dt>
           <dd><em>bhogin</em> mfn. (for 2. col. 3) furnished with windings or curves or rings, curved, ringed (as a serpent) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dt>bhoga 2</dt>
           <dd><em>bhoga</em> m. (&#x221a;3. <em>bhuj</em>) enjoyment, eating, feeding on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (with Jainas 'enjoying once', as opp. to <em>upa-bhoga</em>, q.v.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; use, application <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS">G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fruition, usufruct, use of a deposit &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sexual enjoyment <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; enj&#x1e6d;enjoyment of the earth or of a country i.e. rule, sway <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;rkP">M&#x0101;rkP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; experiencing, feeling, perception (of pleasure or pain) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; profit, utility, advantage, pleasure, delight <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any object of enjoyment (as food, a festival &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; possession, property, wealth, revenue <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; hire, wages (esp. of prostitution) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in astron.) the passing through a constellation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the part of the ecliptic occupied by each of the 27 lunar mansions <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x016b;ryas">S&#x016b;ryas.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in arithm.) the numerator of a fraction (?) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a teacher <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. N. of a Sur&#x00e2;&#x1e45;gan&#x0101; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Si&#x1e43;h&#x00e2;s">Si&#x1e43;h&#x00e2;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. w&#x1e5b;. for <em>bhogya</em> or <em>bh&#x0101;gya</em></dd>

           <dd><em>bhog&#x012b;na</em> mfn. (ifc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 5-1, 9 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 1 and 2 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> (cf. <em>pit&#x1e5b;-bhog&#x012b;&#x1e47;a</em>, <em>m&#x0101;t&#x1e5b;-bh&#x25cb;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; bhogya </dt>
           <dd><em>bh&#x00f3;gya</em> mfn. to be enjoyed, to be used (in the sense 'to be eaten' <em>bhojya</em> is more common), what may be enjoyed or used, useful, profitable <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be endured or suffered <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in astron.) to be passed <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x016b;ryas">S&#x016b;ryas.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. a harlot <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. an object of enjoyment, possession, money <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; corn, grain <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a precious stone <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; bhojas </dt>
           <dd><em>bhojas</em> <em>puru-bh&#x00f3;jas</em>, <em>vi&#x015b;v&#x00e1;-bh&#x25cb;</em>, <em>su-bh&#x00f3;jas</em> (cf. <em>bh&#x00f3;jase</em> under 3. &#x221a;<em>bhuj</em>, p. 759, col. 2)</dd>

           <dd><em>bhojin</em> mfn. (ifc.) enjoying, eating <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y">L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; using, possessing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; bhojya </dt>
           <dd><em>bhojya</em> mfn. to be enjoyed or eaten, eatable, what is enjoyed or eaten, (esp.) what may be eaten without mastication <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhpr">Bhpr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MaitrUp">MaitrUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be enjoyed or used <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#B&#x0101;lar">B&#x0101;lar.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be enjoyed sexually <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to be suffered or experienced <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be fed, one to whom food must be given <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (fr. Caus.) to be made to eat, to be fed <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kull">Kull.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. pl. N. of a people <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;rkP">M&#x0101;rkP.</a> (prob. w&#x1e5b;. for <em>bhoja</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. a procuress <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gal">Gal.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a princess of the Bhojas         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> (cf. <em>bhoj&#x0101;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. anything to be enjoyed or eaten, nourishment, food <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the act of eating, a meal <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> </dd>

           <dt>bhos </dt>
           <dd><em>bhos</em> (fr. <em>bhavas</em> voc. of <em>bhavat</em>, q.v </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; before vowels and soft consonants <em>bho</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; before hard consonants <em>bhos</em> and <em>bho&#x1e25;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the latter form also in pause, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 8-3, 17 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but there is occasional confusion of these forms, esp. in later literature </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; often also <em>bhobho&#x1e25;</em>.), an interjection or voc. particle commonly used in addressing another person or several persons = O! Ho! Hallo l, in soliloquies = alas! <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (according to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> a particle of sorrow and of interrogation)</dd>

           <dt>bhauma </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x221a;">&#x221a;.</a><em>bh&#x1e5b;j</em>) <em>bh&#x1e5b;jj&#x00e1;ti</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a> only forms of the pr. P., and pf. <em>babhrajja</em> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>bhrak&#x1e63;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em>, <em>bhark&#x1e63;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>bh&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;v&#x0101;</em>), to fry, parch, roast (esp. grain) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS">G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS.</a> &amp;c.: Pass. <em>bh&#x1e5b;jjyate</em> (ep. also <em>&#x25cb;ti</em> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to move or roam about (aor.) <em>abibhramat</em> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p769-3"></a>[Page 769, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; B. <em>ababhramat</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a>: Desid. <em>bibhrami&#x1e63;ati</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>bambhram&#x012b;ti</em>, <em>bambhramyate</em> (also with pass. meaning) and <em>bambhr&#x0101;nti</em> (only Gr.), to roam about repeatedly or frequently, wander through, circumambulate         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Var">Var.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;atr">&#x015a;atr.</a> [Cf.
